{{flag|United Nations}} | subject = Export of grain and related foodstuffs and [[fertilizer]]s | purpose = | wikisource = Initiative on the Safe Transportation of Grain and Foodstuffs from Ukrainian Ports }} The '''Black Sea Grain Initiative'''{{cite news |date=27 July 2022 |title=Joint Coordination Centre opens in Istanbul to facilitate safe export of commercial foodstuffs and fertilizers from Ukrainian ports |language=en |work=reliefweb.int |publisher=[[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/turkiye/joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and-fertilizers-ukrainian-ports |url-status=live |access-date=31 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220731003627/https://reliefweb.int/report/turkiye/joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and-fertilizers-ukrainian-ports |archive-date=31 July 2022}} (or the '''Initiative on the Safe Transportation of Grain and Foodstuffs from Ukrainian ports'''; commonly called the '''grain deal''' in the media) was an agreement among [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Turkey]] and the [[United Nations]] (UN) during the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine]]. The invasion in February 2022 led to a complete halt of maritime grain shipments from Ukraine, previously a [[Economy of Ukraine#Agriculture|major exporter]] via the Black Sea. Additionally Russia temporarily halted its grain exports, further exacerbating the situation. This resulted in a rise in world food prices and the threat of famine in lower-income countries, and accusation that Russia was weaponizing food supplies.{{Cite web |last=Prange |first=Astrid |date=May 28, 2022 |title=Fact check: Are food supplies being weaponized?|url=https://www.dw.com/en/fact-check-is-hunger-being-used-as-a-weapon-in-the-ukraine-war/a-61955916 |access-date=June 8, 2023 |website=[[DW News]]}} To address the issue, discussions began in April, hosted by Turkey (which [[Montreaux Convention|controls]] the [[Turkish straits|maritime routes from the Black Sea]]) and supported by the UN. The resulting agreement was signed in [[Istanbul]] on 22 July, valid for a period of 120 days. The July agreement created procedures to safely export grain from certain ports to attempt to address a [[2022–2023 food crises|worldwide food crisis]]. A joint coordination and inspection center was set up in Turkey, with the UN serving as [[Secretariat (administrative office)|secretariat]]. The original agreement was set to expire on 19 November 2022. Russia suspended its participation in the agreement for several days due to a drone attack on Russian naval ships elsewhere in the Black Sea, but rejoined following mediation.{{Cite news |date=2022-11-02 |title=Putin: We could quit grain deal again, but would not block grain for Turkey |language=en |work=Reuters |access-date=November 17, 2022 |website=[[The Moscow Times]]}} In March 2023, Turkey and the UN announced that they secured a second extension for at least another 60 days.{{Cite news |last1=Erkoyun |first1=Ezgi |last2=Soldatkin |first2=Vladimir |date=5 March 2023 |title=Turkey says it is working to renew Black Sea grain deal |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |editor-last=Sithole-Matarise |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230315045542/https://www.reuters.com/world/turkey-says-working-renew-black-sea-grain-deal-2023-03-05/ |archive-date=15 March 2023}} In May 2023, the deal was once again extended for 60 days, expiring on 18 July.{{Cite news |last=Liffey |first=Kevin |date=2023-05-17 |title=Russia confirms Black Sea grain deal renewed for two months |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |editor-last=Smith |editor-first=Alexander |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-confirms-black-sea-grain-deal-renewed-two-months-2023-05-17/ |url-status=live |url-access=registration |access-date=2023-05-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230526105036/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-confirms-black-sea-grain-deal-renewed-two-months-2023-05-17/ |archive-date=26 May 2023}} By mid-July 2023, more than 1000 voyages had successfully left Ukrainian ports carrying nearly 33 million tonnes of grain and other food products to 45 countries. In summer 2023, Russia repeatedly claimed it would withdraw from the deal in July 2023 unless its demands were met.{{Cite news |date=2023-06-21 |title=Kremlin says 'no grounds' to extend grain deal |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/kremlin-says-no-grounds-extend-grain-deal-2023-06-21/ |url-status=live |url-access=registration |access-date=2023-07-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230704115706/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/kremlin-says-no-grounds-extend-grain-deal-2023-06-21/ |archive-date=4 July 2023}}{{Cite web |last=Di Sario |first=Federica |date=2023-06-10 |title=Moscow threatens to walk away from grain deal if export requests aren't met |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/moscow-russia-ukraine-war-threatens-to-walk-away-from-grain-deal-if-export-requests-arent-met/ |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=POLITICO |language=en}} By July 17, 2023, no new agreement to renew the deal had been reached, causing the deal to expire.{{cite web |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/07/1138532 |title=One year of the Black Sea Initiative: Key facts and figures |date=10 July 2023 |access-date=17 July 2023}} ==Background== {{see also|2022–2023 food crises}} In 2022, 47 million people were estimated to be suffering from severe hunger as a result of the world's soaring food costs partly due to the impact of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]]. Developing and emerging countries in [[Africa]], [[Asia]], and [[Latin America]] have been impacted the most by this war due to their reliance on imported grain and fuel.{{cite web |last1=Watson |first1=Cameron |title=Metis Insights: Black Sea Grain Initiative Analysis |url=https://channel16.dryadglobal.com/metis-insights-black-sea-grain-initiative-analysis |website=channel16.dryadglobal.com |publisher=Dryad Global |access-date=31 July 2022 |language=en |date=26 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135106/https://channel16.dryadglobal.com/metis-insights-black-sea-grain-initiative-analysis |url-status=live }} According to the UN [[Food and Agriculture Organization]], Ukraine is among the world's leading grain exporters, providing more than 45 million tonnes annually to the global market.{{cite news |title=Black Sea grain exports deal 'a beacon of hope' amid Ukraine war – Guterres |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/07/1123062 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=UN News |date=22 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801042309/https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/07/1123062 |url-status=live }} Some 20 million tonnes of grain had been held up in the Ukrainian port city of [[Odesa]], according to the [[BBC]].{{cite news |title=Food crisis: Ukraine grain export deal reached with Russia, says Turkey |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-62254597 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=BBC News |date=22 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801023441/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-62254597 |url-status=live }} Almost all of Ukraine's wheat, corn, and sunflower oil were exported through its Black Sea ports prior to the conflict. Before the agreement, some ports' infrastructure has been harmed while others are under Russian control and others are blocked by mines.{{cite news |last1=Youssef |first1=Nancy |title=Mines, Port Damage Threaten Revival of Sea Route for Ukraine Grain |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mines-port-damage-threaten-revival-of-sea-route-for-ukraine-grain-11656754200 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2 July 2022 |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135105/https://www.wsj.com/articles/mines-port-damage-threaten-revival-of-sea-route-for-ukraine-grain-11656754200 |url-status=live }} Initially, the Ukrainian government was reluctant to de-mine the sea due to the scale of the task and the possibility of leaving the ports open to attack.{{cite news |last1=Boffey |first1=Daniel |title=Plan to ship grain out of Ukraine dealt blow due to mines |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/07/plan-to-ship-grain-out-of-ukraine-dealt-blow-by-russian-sea-mines |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=The Guardian |date=7 June 2022 |language=en |archive-date=1 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220801135105/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/07/plan-to-ship-grain-out-of-ukraine-dealt-blow-by-russian-sea-mines |url-status=live }} The grain deal initiative ran from July 2022 to July 2023 before it was not extended by Russia. == Agreement == [[File:Signing Ceremony of the Black Sea Grain Initiative in Istanbul.png|thumb|The signing ceremony in Istanbul on 22 July 2022]] On July 22, 2022, the signing ceremony took place at [[Dolmabahçe Palace]] in Istanbul, Turkey.{{cite news |title=Russia, Ukraine seal landmark grain deal in Istanbul |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/2352336/russia-ukraine-seal-landmark-grain-deal-in-istanbul |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=Bangkok Post |date=23 July 2022 }} The ceremony marks the first major deal between the warring sides since the beginning of the Russian invasion in February.{{cite news |title=Ukraine and Russia sign vital grain export deal in Istanbul |url=https://www.euronews.com/2022/07/21/ukraine-russia-to-sign-turkey-brokered-grain-export-agreement-on-friday |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=euronews |date=21 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=3 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220803210054/http://www.euronews.com/2022/07/21/ukraine-russia-to-sign-turkey-brokered-grain-export-agreement-on-friday |url-status=live }} However, it was not a direct agreement between Russia and Ukraine. Instead, Ukraine signed an agreement with Turkey and the UN, and Russia signed a separate "mirror" agreement with Turkey and the UN.{{cite news |last1=Kareem |first1=Fahim |title=Russia and Ukraine agree to release blockaded grain exports |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/07/22/ukraine-grain-deal-turkey-russia/ |access-date=2 August 2022 |newspaper=Washington Post |date=22 July 2022 |archive-date=11 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220811044039/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/07/22/ukraine-grain-deal-turkey-russia/ |url-status=live }} The signed documents entail the safe navigation for the export of grain and related foodstuffs and fertilizers. The ships would traverse the [[Black Sea]] in specially created corridors that are [[Demining|demined]], with Turkey inspecting all merchant vessels.{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Dorian |title=Agreement Signed on Trapped Ukrainian Grain |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/agreement-signed-on-trapped-ukrainian-grain/6669944.html |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=VOA |date=22 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=31 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220731151015/https://www.voanews.com/a/agreement-signed-on-trapped-ukrainian-grain/6669944.html |url-status=live }} Another agreement was concurrently made for the UN to facilitate unimpeded exports of Russian food, fertilizer and raw materials.{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/sg/en/content/sg/note-correspondents/2022-07-22/note-correspondents-today%E2%80%99s-agreements |title=Note to correspondents on today's agreements |publisher=United Nations |date=22 July 2022 |access-date=2 August 2022 |archive-date=2 August 2022 Coordination Centre === As part of the agreement, a Joint Coordination Centre (JCC) was created under the auspices of the UN in Istanbul on July 27.{{cite news |title=Joint Coordination Centre opens in Istanbul to facilitate safe export of commercial foodstuffs and fertilizers from Ukrainian ports |url=https://ukraine.un.org/en/192320-joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=ukraine.un.org |date=27 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=5 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005011516/https://ukraine.un.org/en/192320-joint-coordination-centre-opens-istanbul-facilitate-safe-export-commercial-foodstuffs-and |url-status=live }} The JCC is tasked with registering and monitoring the departure of commercial ships via satellite, internet, and other communication means. Its primary responsibility is to check for the absence of unauthorized cargo and personnel on board of the vessels.{{cite news |title=Agreement On Unblocking Grain Exports From Ukrainian Ports Signed In Istanbul |url=https://en.cfts.org.ua/news/agreement_on_unblocking_grain_exports_from_ukrainian_ports_signed_in_istanbul |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=en.cfts.org.ua |date=25 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=5 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005011517/https://en.cfts.org.ua/news/agreement_on_unblocking_grain_exports_from_ukrainian_ports_signed_in_istanbul |url-status=live }} The JCC is located on the campus of the [[National Defense University (Turkey)|National Defense University]], about seven kilometers north of the center of Istanbul. The center is headed by a Turkish admiral. A total of 20 delegates are employed (five representatives from the four involved parties each). Ukrainians and Russians work separately from each other and contact between them happens only in emergency situations if deemed necessary.{{cite news |title=Grain coordination centre set to launch in Istanbul |url=https://www.trtworld.com/turkey/grain-coordination-centre-set-to-launch-in-istanbul-59177 |access-date=1 August 2022 |work=TRT World |date=27 July 2022 |language=en |archive-date=1
